üèÉ ACTIVITY LEVEL: You reported low physical activity. 20 minutes of daily moderate exercise increases 'adenosine' (sleep pressure), helping you fall asleep faster.

description: High activity but trouble falling asleep
advice: üèÉ TIMING EXERCISE: You are very active but struggle to sleep. Ensure you finish high-intensity workouts 3 hours before bed to allow your core body temperature to drop.

description: Poor room quality specifically due to noise (implied)
advice: üîä NOISE MASKING: If noise is the issue, do not rely on silence. Use 'Pink Noise' or 'Brown Noise' (deeper than White Noise) to mask sudden sounds.
‚òï CAFFEINE (INSOMNIA PROTOCOL): Because you show signs of Insomnia, you must have a strict caffeine cutoff at 2:00 PM. Caffeine has a half-life of ~6 hours.
‚òï CAFFEINE HABIT: Drinking caffeine after 6 PM reduces deep sleep (Stage 3), even if you fall asleep easily. Switch to herbal tea or decaf in the evening.
‚òï JITTER CYCLE: High caffeine intake + High stress is a vicious cycle. Caffeine mimics the symptoms of anxiety (racing heart). Try cutting back to reduce bedtime racing thoughts.
üç∑ ALCOHOL & APNEA: Alcohol relaxes the throat muscles, which significantly worsens snoring and apnea events. It is highly recommended to avoid alcohol entirely before bed.
üç∑ THE REBOUND EFFECT: You wake up too early. This is a classic sign of alcohol metabolization. As alcohol wears off, your brain spikes into alertness. Skip the nightcap.
üç∑ ALCOHOL TRAP: Alcohol helps you fall asleep initially but destroys REM sleep quality. It is a sedative, not a sleep aid. Avoid it 3 hours before bed.
ü•ó DIET & APNEA: Heavy meals close to bedtime increase pressure on the diaphragm and worsen Apnea/Snoring events. Finish eating 3 hours before sleep.
ü•ó DIGESTION: Heavy meals require energy to digest, raising your body temperature. This conflicts with the body's need to cool down for sleep.
üí° LIGHT (CRSD PROTOCOL): Your internal clock is out of sync. You MUST avoid blue light (screens) for 2 hours before bed to allow melatonin production.
üì± DIGITAL SUNSET: Blue light from screens suppresses melatonin. Try using 'Night Shift' mode or blue-light blocking glasses in the evening.
üîå TECH DETOX: You admitted technology hurts your sleep. Charge your phone in the kitchen (not the bedroom) and buy a standard alarm clock.
üì± DOOMSCROLLING LOOP: You have high stress and high tech usage. Checking news/social media at night triggers cortisol. Replace the phone with a physical book.
‚ù§Ô∏è SOCIAL CONNECTION: Loneliness keeps the brain in a 'hyper-vigilant' state. Scheduling a quick call with a friend or family member in the evening can lower cortisol levels.
üß† BRAIN DUMP: Racing thoughts at night? Try writing a 'To-Do' list for tomorrow 2 hours before bed. This offloads the worry from your working memory.
üß† MOOD & SLEEP: You noted mood affects your sleep. This relationship is bidirectional. Consider tracking your mood and sleep in a journal to identify triggers.

description: Napping is actually good for Narcolepsy
advice: üí§ NAPPING (NARCOLEPSY): Unlike insomnia patients, scheduled short naps (15-20 mins) can be very beneficial for managing narcolepsy symptoms.
üí§ NAP STRATEGY: Long naps (>30 mins) steal 'sleep pressure' from the night, making it harder to fall asleep. Limit naps to 20 minutes (Power Nap).
üõèÔ∏è STIMULUS CONTROL: Stop working, eating, or watching TV in bed. Your brain needs to associate the bed ONLY with sleep and intimacy.

description: High snoring but not fully Apnea yet
advice: üõå SNORING TIP: Loud snoring is often positional. Try the 'Tennis Ball Technique': sew a tennis ball into the back of a t-shirt to prevent rolling onto your back.
üî• RLS RELIEF: For leg discomfort, try alternating hot and cold packs on your legs before bed, or a warm bath to relax the muscles.
üëª NIGHTMARES: Frequent nightmares can be managed with 'Imagery Rehearsal Therapy' (IRT). Write down the bad dream during the day, change the ending to something positive, and visualize it.
üßò SLEEP PARALYSIS: This phenomenon, while scary, is harmless. It happens when your mind wakes up before your body's REM atonia wears off. Focus on moving just one finger to break the state.
ü©∏ RLS CHECK: Restless Legs Syndrome is often caused by low iron levels (Ferritin). Consult your doctor for a blood test.

description: Women are more prone to RLS
advice: üö∫ RLS & GENDER: RLS is more common in women, often linked to hormonal changes or iron deficiency anemia. Ensure your diet is rich in iron/magnesium.
üõå POSITIONAL THERAPY: Apnea is often worse when sleeping on your back. Try sleeping on your side to keep airways open.
üöπ APNEA RISK: Men are statistically 2-3 times more likely to have Sleep Apnea due to anatomical differences in the upper airway. Do not ignore snoring.
üîí SAFETY FIRST: Since you have signs of Parasomnia (Sleepwalking), ensure windows and doors are locked and remove tripping hazards from your bedroom.
üß† CBT-I: The Gold Standard treatment for Insomnia is Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I), not pills. Look for an app or therapist specializing in this.
